I agree with this article. My kids and I moved here last summer and I had been advised that they should only attend private schools.  But, I chose to give the public schools a chance so we could really become part of the community we planned to settle in.  I am SO HAPPY we followed our heart on this.  Jefferson Elementary and Washington Middle School are awesome schools. The teachers are wonderful (caring and very competent).  Regardless of public or private schools, parents HAVE to be involved in their children's education to help them be successful - it cannot be fully in the school's lap. Ultimately, it is in all of our best interest to support our public schools.

"The decline reflected the devastating effects from Hurricanes Harvey and Irma"

"Hurricanes Harvey and Irma damaged not only Texas and Florida but also the U.S. jobs picture, as payrolls fell by 33,000 in September. That drop came even as the unemployment rate fell to a 16-year low of 4.2 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday.
The jobs loss was the first monthly decline in seven years, when the economy was still pulling out of the Great Recession.
Even with the surprise jobs number, the closely watched hourly wages figure jumped higher, to an annualized rate of 2.9 percent."

LFS: In a response to my invitation to you for coffee or a beer, Don R. compares me with Jehovah's Witnesses.  Of course, he means this disparagingly.  However, I'm flattered to be so compared.  While, as an agnostic, I don't agree with their message, I honor and respect Jehovah's Witnesses for their faith and dedication.  They "knock on doors" in an effort to spread their beliefs and, in so doing, face ridicule, insults and, sadly enough, threats of violence.....that's true dedication.

I'm not quite as dedicated, but I do enjoy an exchange of views with others.  Will I share some of my views if we meet...of course I will.  Will we agree and disagree, of course we will.  Will we go away with an increased understanding of each other......I certainly hope so.  regards, Gary

If you use your real name to post anything on the web, expect someone, perhaps the owners of the comments system (and maybe not the current, but future ones) to collect, tabulate and sell that information to people, companies and organizations you wouldn't want to have it. Expect people of strongly opposing views to look up your publicly available property ownership records, business ownership records and phone numbers to vandalize, damage business or otherwise violate your privacy. Expect potential employers, landlords, insurers, loan companies, etc. to Google your name and use your views to discriminate against you. On the other hand, if they cannot find any of your views, they may use that to discriminate against you. Welcome to the brave new world of the searchable web and Big Data. Anonymity does sometimes inhibit responsible behavior, but it wards off a whole host of other evils when used properly. So please don think poorly of those of us who decide to take advantage of it.

Some of the guilty have always walked free. Resource constraints affect the whole system. At the very front end, minor crimes are often not even reported because the victims simply don't have the time to waste; the police do not put a high priority on the efficient use of complainants' time. Next, there are not enough police to thoroughly investigate the crimes that come to their attention, much less to detect all the crimes that are committed. The few criminals that actually get caught then face the first prosecution filter "is there a substantial likelihood of conviction". Those that pass that hurdle then are filtered by "is it in the public interest to proceed" which is where Alberta's triage strategy comes in.
Once you're past the prosecution filters, there are constraints on available court time. After that, we sometimes have the problem that the jails are full. Resource constraints are not going to go away because you think they are "bad policy".

Linda Shaw, you hit the very essence of the Denali wolf drama.   Thank you.  What she advocates is the multiple use principle so many favor in natural resource and public land use debates  vs. the single  use mantra.  
Denali wildlife managed for multiple uses yes, e.g.: photograph, observe and experience by the multitudes and that's hundreds of thousands of observer-wisitors, also  a major economic driver for the Denali region and the state of Alaska. And, as in wolf, maintaining a healthy ecosystem  functioning as  a valuable  keystone predator  keeping a  population of  ungulates in balance with their habitat. The single use is trapping, killing by a few hunters and trappers of park wolves  lured outside protective park with bait stations, killed by that  hunter/ trapper, never to be seen nor experienced again, ever.  Single use. Multiple use. It's the essence of the  debate.  It applies here.  Multiple, continuing use of Denali wolves and  other resident wildlife! Thank you Linda.

I've been driving the 2007 version of this car (335i) for 7 years and over 100K. if you use it as a 2-seater with the cargo platform down over the rear seats, you have a fabulous tourer with loads of luggage space -- even with the top down. We've driven to California and back twice -- top down when the sun shines, and still able to take it through a car wash (which I would never do with my soft top car). I rented a 428 convertible in Florida for a week this past spring. Nice car although a bit tamer and softer than I was used to (maybe the 440 has better driving feel?). Biggest ergonomic complaint is that BMW has switched back to putting the cruise control switches on the steering wheel -- a really dumb move. The third stalk cruise control on my older bimmers is so much more intuitive and easy to use without taking your eyes off the road. I'll probably look for one of the last 335s when it's time to replace mine.

The sadness comes less from a inconsistencies between what the church puts forth and science, or the many questions that can arise when one tries to apply logic to what the church teaches.   Rather, the sadness comes from the realization that what we've learned from science since the last such position taken offers church leaders a chance to dig deeper, to expound in more depth, and to take us somewhere new.

Here, the church has a great opportunity to reflect on the nature of death, the soul, and an afterlife.  Which is more important: that we understand the details of how "resurrection" works with our physical bodies, or the very concept that there could be something more, even if we don't fully understand it, and perhaps how we might begin to think about that 'something more?'  Common sense and science leave a TON of questions to be answered.  Why not take us to new theological insight?

BOE members are volunteers - people who give their free time to work for the community. They cannot micromanage the DOE.  I think the BOE could provide better oversight of BOE policies, but with regard to the survey, I believe they asked DOE HR to come up with a list of qualifications to aid in the search. The DOE attempted to include the public in creating a list, but as usual, it was the old ineffective, top-down method which starts with a select group of people deciding what questions to ask. A more effective model of creating surveys to poll stakeholders is to start at the ground level, and develop questions with feedback from affected stakeholders working on the front lines. Then, develop a survey with those questions.  Where the BOE is responsible for the survey conundrum is in not setting policies that require survey questions be created by those on the front lines of whatever the survey seeks to find out, and continuing to tolerate this top-down system.

Agreed.  Rwanda was about enmity and prejudice between Hutu and Tutsi populations that came to a boil under economic pressures and competition in Rwanda and Burundi.   The Hutu and Tutsi had the same language, religion and culture.   The main difference was that the Tutsi were aristocratic herders of cattle and the majority Hutu were peasant farmers.   There is about a 12-cm difference in height between the average tall Tutsi and the average short Hutu.   This is about the same as the difference in height between wealthy and poor Europeans in the 19th and 20th centuries.

This genocide had nothing to do with racism.   It was about prejudice or bias.

There are only four major race classifications on the planet according to anthropologists.   The words race, racism and racist are often misused to describe other forms of prejudice.

The big problem with speaker invitations is that the system around them is quite bad at the moment. Any small group can request somebody be invited to speak, and only need a small bit of support from the faculty to make this happen.
There is no consultation with the rest of the faculty body nor the students prior to doing so, and no system for building consensus on who deserves the high honor of having their views validated by being allowed to speak them at a university. So the only way to register disagreement against an invitation is by protesting after the invitation is sent. A more consultative system of invitation would eradicate those protests entirely.
More importantly though - the protests actually prove the diversity of views prevalent and respected on campusses. If the accusation of ideological conformity was true - there would be no protests since there would be no holders of other views to request the unpopular invitations in the first place.

Marijuana has been popular among teenagers in Canada and the US  for about 50 years. If it caused brain damage in teenage users, we should be seeing the effect in all age groups up to about 65. Where are the hordes of people suffering from brain damage due to teenage pot smoking?

I don't see clearly damaged pot smokers, outside of anti-drug commercials.

I relate to this issue. I teach at Western Ontario, and I am uncomfortable with the standard practice of granting extensions because of illness for the same reasons outlined by the author. Two years ago, I tried to combat this problem by telling the class that everyone would be given a one-week extension for any assignments without the need of any kind of documentation. I thought that this would help students manage their time and relieve the schedules of doctors and the students themselves. Unfortunately, all but a small number of students simply treated the one-week extension as the new due date and the same problems appeared, only a week later. My idea needs work, but I would like to see how effective it could be if a critical mass of classes adopted the same policy: students might learn to set their own deadlines if they had that ability in all of their classes.

Dealing with makeup tests is another story.

Thank you Tina for your reply. I agree with your point about appropriation being an artifact of power dynamics and that it is not reversible; if the hegemony coopts a story from a subjugated people, the risk of appropriation is quite high. Almost (but not completely) unavoidable. If a subjugated people tells a story not their own, on the other hand, cultural appropriation is less of a pitfall (though not absolutely zero). And in the case of multimillion-dollar feature films, the profits benefit the studio, not the culture from which the story comes--this, to me, is the biggest issue.  

However, it does not follow that because there are a lot of Jewish people in Hollywood, a film made by a non-Jew about the Holocaust would (or wouldn't) be a form of appropriation. That is a non-sequitur that itself borders on racist, though I don't think you meant it that way. And I do urge you to watch "Embrace of the Serpent" for an excellent cinematic treatment of an indigenous story.

So the answer to your initial question of how long they can keep Cargo on the field should be "as long as they keep winning baseball games."

A car hitting anything causes measurable damage, sometimes catastrophic damage, and insurance makes sense.  A bicycle hitting something generally doesn't cause much more than a couple of scratches to the hittee, notwithstanding the one or two collisions that happen every year when some ID10T hits a ped while racing on a multi-use path or something similar.  How could it - most cyclists don't go much faster than 20kph and weigh something like 90 kg, compared to a car travelling at 40kph and weighing 2000 kg, which translates to about 400 times the force when a car hits something (hey science boys, did i get that calc right??).  The potential downside doesn't justify insurance.

Basic rule -  refugees are not immigrants.  

Refugees are permitted by our law to enter Canada legally or illegally and seek protection per the Immigration and REFUGEE PROTECTION Act (IRPA) implementing our international obligations per the various international conventions relating to refugee protection.  Note s. 133 that exempts refugees from charges for illegal entry to Canada.

Persons who claim refugee status and remain in Canada as permanent residents are a tiny percentage of the yearly landings of immigrants known as Refugees Landed in Canada class (RLC)  The greatest number of immigrants come under the economic classes and are subject to the points system.  In 2010 only 3% of total landings were by the RLC class.  And the RLC do better economically than government sponsored refugees.  Earnings lag slightly compared to Canadians but by year five they catch up.

See Refugees Landed in Canada - Findings from the Longitudinal Immigration Database (IMDB) published in March 2012

Yes, Hawaii history like all of history leaves huge gray areas.  Prior to  the Samoa based Pa'ao migration, Hawaii was very different in governance and traditions.  By 1550 CE, all the islands had become very different from their ancient traditions and governance.  By 1778, Capt. Cook found a native archipelago long changed from its ancient roots and immersed in royal wars and human sacrifices.  Even King Kalakaua's 1880 "Kumulipo" established his ku'auhau to Pilikaeaea, the Tahiti area chief of the Pa'ao migration.  The influx of Ulu lineal priests changed this ancient archipelagos's Nanaulu based governance dramatically over the ensuing several centuries.  The Big Island's Mo'i, Kalanilulumoku, was quite diluted with the Ulu ku'auhau by the time he birthed Liloa.   Often, "fakes" are just progressions through history applicable to all peoples.

Interesting point raised here, about the value of hunting to many, over and above the cost to individuals.

The most important discussion, it seems to me, is how much our state Department of Fish and Game should spend state money on management activities that facilitate moose and caribou meat hunting, even when the costs per pound of meat, when everything is toted up, are not competitive with grocery prices. 

Of course the department must protect the resource, but spend millions 'enhancing' the resource for meat hunters? If hunting for many is a choice, how much government assistance for that choice is proper?

I can see how rural areas without easy access and where hunting is less a choice than a necessity -- rural residents may need support at times. For the rest, some serious reconsideration of Fish and Game intensive management standards is due. This is not an anti-meat hunting stance, but let's not be afraid of some self-examination here.

I also thought that the Ontario Liberals said the new carbon tax would be revenue neutral.  I was challenged on that by another commenter and could not find any articles that say it would be.  Do you have a reference for Ontario Cap&Trade being touted as revenue-neutral?

You're quite right in pointing out the absurdity in the government's statement that revenue-neutrality would be achieved by new spending.  Revenue-neutrality means that new revenues collected by the government are offset by foregoing revenues from another source, not by spending that new revenue.  I don't see this government foregoing any current revenue streams at all.

Oh, and BTW, don't forget that the Federal government is reaping a windfall benefit from the Ontario carbon tax of roughly M$54 a year in GST charged on the carbon tax (StatsCan http://www.statcan.gc.ca/tables-tableaux/sum-som/l01/cst01/trade37b-eng.htm and $20/ton carbon tax).  ON PST gets M$87.

Given that I am nearly 79, I have many pleasant memories of rail trips before Amtrak, including two that were cross-country with good food, Pullman sleepers and excellent service. It was true that if you wanted to take a train to Spokane, for example, you would have to use Great Northern. But if you wanted to go to Chicago, there was more than one option. This  reminds me of when I was a student in a "Problems of Democracy" class at Marshfield High School back in 1953.  As a class project, two of us  took  extracts from the  Declaration of Independence, placed them on a petition, and went door to door in Coos Bay-
As I recall, the sections we included were:
"whenever any form of government becomes destructive to these ends, it is the right of the people to alter or to abolish it, and to institute new government, laying its foundation on such principles, and organizing its powers in such forms, as to them shall seem most likely to effect their safety and happiness."
Also:
"But when a long train of abuses and usurpations, pursuing invariably the same object, evinces a design to reduce them under absolute despotism, it is their right, it is their duty, to throw off such government, and to provide new guards for their future security."
Almost nobody signed, and  the resulting newspaper headline was "THOMAS JEFFERSON DECLARED COMMUNIST."

The rail ridership projections in the alternatives analysis and the EIS were projected under the assumption that only the rail project is built and everything else says the same.  They did not take into account any other land use or transportation policies.  Rail is a tool that can be used to help increase transportation alternatives and reduce traffic congestion, but it is certainly not the only tool available to the City.  The City can increase rail ridership by changing zoning codes to allow for greater mixes of uses and lower parking requirements near the transit stations (TOD policies) as well as by building more bike lanes, better sidewalks and promoting other transportation alternatives such as carsharing and bikesharing.  All of these policy changes and transportation choice improvements are already underway in Honolulu.  The home run policy the City/State could institute would be congestion pricing during peak traffic hours on the H-1 freeway.

Our economy is more dependent on international and US economic trends and financial policies than on what our PMs and governments do to influence growth and solvency.  As Dalton Camp observed, "Washington makes the laws.  Ottawa makes the bi-laws".

But Canadian PMs and their policies can make the best or the worst of the global and US hands they are dealt.  PMs making the best of bad hands - as Harper did during the global melt down - tend to be trusted by the electorate and get re-elected.  Those who make the worst of bad hands lose their economic credibility and the trust of Canadians and are punished at the polls.

Trudeau 1.0 played his economic and fiscal hands disastrously and voters outside Quebec got wise to this and lost trust in his economic stewardship.  So he squeaked in by just 2 seats in 1972, lost in 1979, and doomed the Liberals to defeat in 1984.

Trudeau 2.0 seems to be following his father`s course and therefore can expect the same result.

There are no cost estimates that can show that it is feasibly economical to provide  either gas or electricity to the villages and have them pay their way, it's impossible. It's about as uneconomic as using the saved state money to dole it out bit by bit to keep the state afloat. A DC electric line 850 miles and getting the state relying in it for uninterrupted power is also a pipe dream. There are only two reliable sources of electricity and of gas, the dam and a pipeline of reasonable size to the slope to service the state. Heating with electricity statewide won't ever happen but supplementing the gas like goes on now is feasible. It's sad to say but forget the villages unless they can afford in the future to hook up to the main lines themselves.
